Module 1: Impurity in Racket

Preparation: Side Effects, Parsing, Features in Racket & C

Side Effects

Full Racket permits several expressions to appear, instead of just one in the teaching languages. They are all evaluated, but only the value of the last one is used. The others are evaluated for their side effects, and any value they produce is discarded.

begin

  • Grammar rules and rewrite rules:

     
    ​x
    1
    exp = (begin exp exp ...)
    2
    ​
    3
    (begin val exp ...) => (begin exp ...)
    4
    (begin exp) => exp

  • For example, there is an implicit begin in the body of functions, lambda, and local, and in the answers of cond and match.

Output
  • Before: substitution model from CS 145 allows us to reduce a program to a sequence of definitions and values and they are then printed, one to a line, in the interaction window.
  • Now: Racket allows values to be printed during the computation, and they can also be stored in files. Thus we now treat what appears in the Interactions window as an unbounded sequence of characters that we call the output sequence. A function that performs output simply appends characters to the end of this sequence.
Substitution Model

  • Quadruple

    • : a sequence of programs (definitions and expressions), what we've been working with in the old substitution model.
    • : a sequence of definitions, which are of the form (define id exp).
    • : the output sequence.
    • : the input sequence.

  • We refer to the elements that change during the sequence of rewrites (apart from the simplification of expression in ) as state. We study the consequences of state in this course.

  • Effects of our new model:

    • Order of evaluation matters now: change of order of evaluation would change the output from side-effects.
    • Infinitely running programs are no longer meaningless: previously we rely on the program to finish and produce values, but now we have side-effects.

  • In allowing input, we have given up a property known as referential transparency. Previously, we could replace any expressions in a program by its value, or by another expression that evaluate to the same value, and obtain an equivalent program. However, when we allow output, such a substitution might change the output. A good example would be programs using read, since users may input different values, we cannot really substitute the statement. This makes reasoning about programs more difficult.

Memory Model

  • Memory can be viewed as a sequence of boxes indexed by natural numbers, each one containing a fixed-size number.

  • The memory model serves as an approximation to actual hardware:

 

Racket Language Features

for-each
  • Effect: The function for-each is an abstract list function that works like map, except that it does not produce a list. It consumes a function f and a list lst, applies f to each element of lst, but discards the resulting values and produce only #<void>. Thus this is useful only when the application of f has side effects.

  • Example:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    1
    1
    (for-each (λ (x) (printf "~a" x)) lst)
    • The program displays each element of a list (type doesn't matter), separated by spaces.
    • The value of this entire expression is #<void>.
    • A similar program in C, with the assumption that every element in the array is an integer.
     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    3
    1
    for (i = 0; i < array-size; i++) {
    2
        printf("%d", array[i]);
    3
    }

  • Implementing for-each

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    10
    1
    (define (for-each f lst)
    2
      (cond
    3
       [(empty? lst) (void)] ;; the program produces #<void>.
    4
       [else (f (first lst)) (for-each f (rest lst))])) ;; implicit begin used here.
    5
    ​
    6
    (define (for-each f lst)
    7
      (if (empty? lst)
    8
          (void) 
    9
          (begin (f (first lst)) ;; here we need an explicit begin.
    10
                 (for-each f (rest lst)))))
when and unless

  • (when test body ...): evaluates test, if true, the bodies are evaluated till the last one; otherwise, produce #<void>.

  • (unless test body ...): evaluates test, if false the bodies are evaluated till the last one; otherwise, produce #<void>.

  • Implement for-each using when and unless

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    5
    1
    (define (for-each f lst)
    2
      (when (not (empty? lst)) (f (first lst)) (for-each f (rest lst))))
    3
    ​
    4
    (define (for-each f lst)
    5
      (unless (empty? lst) (begin (f (first lst)) (for-each f (rest lst))))
    • Observe that when and unless can take multiply bodies (expressions).

 

Loops in Racket
for Loop

  • Syntax

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    2
    1
    (for ([id sequence-expr] ...)
    2
         body ...)
    • A for loop iterates through the sequence produced by the sequence-expr. For each element in the sequence, for binds the element to id and then evaluates the bodys for side effects.

  • Example

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    11
    1
    > (for ([i '(1 2 3)])
    2
           (display i))
    3
    123
    4
    ​
    5
    > (for ([i "abc"])
    6
           (printf "~a..." i))
    7
    a...b...c...
    8
    ​
    9
    > (for ([i 4])
    10
           (display i))
    11
    0123
for/list Loop

  • The for/list variant of for is more Racket-like: it accumulates body results into a list, instead of evaluating body only for side effects. In other words, for/list implements a list comprehension -- it evaluates body to obtain values that go into a newly constructed list.

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    11
    1
    > (for/list ([i '(1 2 3)])
    2
              (* i i))
    3
    '(1 4 9)
    4
    ​
    5
    > (for/list ([i "abc"])
    6
                i)
    7
    '(#\a #\b #\c)
    8
    ​
    9
    > (for/list ([i 4])
    10
                i)
    11
    '(0 1 2 3)
in-range Function

  • Generates a sequence of numbers, given an optional starting number (defaults to 0), a number before which the sequences ends (up to but not include), and an optional step (defaults to 1).

  • Using a non-negative integer directly as a sequence is a shorthand for (in-range k).

    • For example, (for ([i 4]) ...) is a shorthand for (for ([i (in-range 4)] ...).
for Loops Traverse in Parallel

  • We can give a for loop multiple [id sequence-expr] clauses:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    6
    1
    > (for ([i (in-range 1 4)]
    2
          [chapter '("Intro" "Details" "Conclusion")])
    3
         (printf ("Chapter ~a. ~a\n" i chapter)))
    4
    Chapter 1. Intro
    5
    Chapter 2. Details
    6
    Chapter 3. Conclusion

  • The for loop stops iterating when any sequence ends. This behavior works great with in-naturals (default start is 0 and step is fixed to be 1, consumes an optional argument as starting pointing) , which creates an infinite sequence of numbers to be used for indexing:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    6
    1
    > (for ([i (in-naturals 1)]
    2
          [chapter '("Intro" "Details" "Conclusion")])
    3
         (printf ("Chapter ~a. ~a\n" i chapter)))
    4
    Chapter 1. Intro
    5
    Chapter 2. Details
    6
    Chapter 3. Conclusion
for* Loops Nest Sequences

  • The for* form, which has the same syntax as for, nests multiple sequences instead of running them in parallel:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    9
    1
    > (for* ([book '("Guide" "Reference")]
    2
             [chapter '("Intro" "Details" "Conclusion")])
    3
            (printf "~a ~a\n" book chapter))
    4
    Guide Intro
    5
    Guide Details
    6
    Guide Conclusion
    7
    Reference Intro
    8
    Reference Details
    9
    Reference Conclusion
for/and and for/or
  • for/and form combines iteration results with and, stopping as soon as it encountered #f.
  • for/or form combines iteration results with or, stopping as soon as it encountered #t.
  • As usual, the for/and and for/or forms provide the same facility with nested iterations.

 

Three Levels of Racket Input Functions

Low Level
  • read-char: removes the character from the input sequence
  • peek-char: reads the character from the input sequence but does not remove the character
Middle Level
  • read-line: removes a whole line from the input sequence
High Level
  • read: produces an S-expression, reading enough of the input to complete one.
Application

  • Implement read-line using read-char

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    10
    1
    (define (read-line)
    2
      (define (rl-helper acc)
    3
        (define ch (read-char)) ;; read one character at a time.
    4
        (cond
    5
         ;; if encounter EOF or newline character, output the string
    6
         [(or (eof-object? ch) (char=? ch #\newline)) 
    7
          (list->string (reverse acc))] 
    8
         ;; otherwise, linear recursion by appending ch to acc
    9
         [else (rl-helper (cons ch acc))]))
    10
      (rl-helper empty))              

  • Implement read-input using read-line

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    5
    1
    (define (read-input)
    2
      (define line (read-line)) ;; read one line at a time.
    3
      (cond
    4
       [(eof-object? line) empty] ;; if encounter EOF, return empty
    5
       [else (cons line (read-input))])) ;; cons line to the next read-line
    • Note that this is NOT tail-recursive. Recall that a function is tail-recursion if the recursion is the "last thing done", that is, the result of the recursive application is the value of the entire function, with no further computation on it.

 

Tokenizing and Parsing

 
xxxxxxxxxx

1
(struct token (type value))
2
;; Types: 'lp, 'rp, 'num, 'id
3
​
4
(define (token-leftpar? x) (symbol=? (token-type x) 'lp))
5
(define (token-rightpar? x) (symbol=? (token-type x) 'rp))
6
​
7
(define list->symbol (λ (lst) (string->symbol (list->string lst))))
8
(define list->number (λ (lst) (string->number (list->string lst))))

10
;; read-id: -> (listof char) 
11
(define (read-id)
12
  (define nc (peek-char))
13
  (if (or (char-alphabetic? nc) (char-numeric? nc))
14
      (cons (read-char) (read-id))
15
      empty))
16
​

;; read-number: -> (listof char)
18
(define (read-number)
19
  (define nc (peek-char))
20
  (if (char-numeric? nc)
21
      (cons (read-char) (read-number))
22
      empty))
23
​
24
;; read-token: -> token
25
(define (read-token)
26
  (define fc (read-char))
27
  (cond
28
   [(char-whitespace? fc) (read-token)]
29
   [(char=? fc #\() (token 'lp fc)]
30
   [(char=? fc #\)) (token 'rp fc)]
31
   [(char-alphabetic? fc)
32
    (token 'id (list->symbol (cons fc (read-id)))]
33
   [(char-numeric? fc)
34
    (token 'num (list->number (cons fc (read-number))))]
35
   [else (error "lexical error")]))  
36
    
37
;; read-list: -> (listof S-exp)
38
(define (read-list)
39
  (define tk (read-token))
40
  (cond
41
    [(token-rightpar? tk) empty]
42
    [(token-leftpar? tk) (cons (read-list) (read-list))]
43
    [else (cons (token-value tk) (read-list))]))
44
 
45
;; my-read: -> S-exp
46
(define (my-read)
47
  (define tk (read-token))
48
    (if (token-leftpar? tk)
49
        (read-list)
50
        (token-value tk)))
Wrapper: my-read
  • Start to read one token, which (in order to be syntactically correct) is either a left parenthesis or an independent number/id. In the second case, since we are only reading enough to produce one S-expression, we can simply output the value of the token. Otherwise, we need to go on and read more.
High level: read-list
  • If the token read is a right parenthesis, return empty (as the base case of this recursively-defined function).
  • If the token read is a left parenthesis, it indicates that we have entered another S-expression, so need to finish reading this new expression before moving on.
  • Think of this as a stack --- each left parenthesis is like adding a new stack and each right parenthesis is like a return statement; if we found another left parenthesis, we create a new stack frame, finish the job there and then pop that stack, return the S-expression we just parsed to the stack frame above and continue working from there. This should explain why we are cons one (read-list) to another.
  • If the token is not a parenthesis, we are reading a number or an id. Thus we cons its token value to whatever we are reading next.
Middle level: read-token
  • There are basically five kinds of tokens, two of them are easy to handle -- whitespace (which we simply ignore), left and right parentheses (translate directly to a token object).
  • If the token is a letter, we are reading an id, so we create an id object, with type being id and go on reading to figure out its value. Note that we need to cons fc to whatever is being read next since we have already consumed the character. The case that token is a number is similar.
Low level: read-id and read-number
  • We keep reading and cons until we encounter a whitespace, in which case we return empty.

 

Introduction to C

Terminology

  • Block: a sequence of statements that is treated as a single statement.

  • Dynamically typed: type-checking at run-time.

    • Racket's contract is for our reference.

  • Statically typed: type-checking at compile-time.

    • C's contract (function declaration) is enforced.

  • Declaration-before-use: provide a forward declaration (also called function header or function prototype).

  • preprocessor directive: a command that is executed by the C preprocessor, a tool that runs automatically before the compiler begins. Its purpose is to transform the program in various ways before the compiler sees it.

Compiling and Linking

  • Creating an executable is a multistage process divided into two components: compilation and linking.

    • Compilation refers to the process of source code files (.c, .cc, .cpp) and the creation of an "object" file.

      • This step doesn't create anything the user can actually run. Instead, the compiler merely produces the machine language instructions that corresponds to the course code file that was compiled. For example, if you compile but don't link three separate files, you will have three object files created as output, each with the extension .o or .obj. Each of these files contains a translation of your source code file into a machine language file, but you will not be able to run them. To turn them into executables your OS can use, you need the linker.

    • Linking refers to the creation of a single executable file from multiple object files.

      • In this step, it is common that the linker will complain about undefined functions (especially the main function itself). During compilation, if the compiler could not find the definition for a particular function, it would just assume that the function was defined in another file. The compiler really don't know more than that since it only looks at the contents of one file at a time. The linker, on the other hand, may look at multiple files and try to find references for the functions that weren't mentioned.

  • One of the main advantage to separate the building process into these two separate stages is that this allows the creation of large programs without having to redo the compilation step every time a file is changed. Instead, using so called "conditional compilation", i.e. compile only those source files that have changed; for the rest, the object files are sufficient input for the linker. Another advantage is that it is simple to implement libraries of pre-compiled code: just create object files and link them just like any other object file.

  • To conclude, compiler errors are usually syntactic in nature -- a missing semicolon, an extra parenthesis, etc.; linking errors usually have to do with missing or multiple definitions.

ASCII

  • American Standard Code for Information Interchange, a character encoding standard for electronic communication.

  • Designed by the American Standards Association (now the American National Standards Institute, ANSI).

  • ASCII encodes 128 specified characters into seven-bit integers; 95 of them are printable; 33 of the original ASCII characters are non-printing control codes which originates with Teletype machines; most of them obsolete now. Here are some interesting ones:

    • 1: SOH, start of heading
    • 2: STX, start of text
    • 7: BEL: Bell
    • 8: BS: backspace
    • 9: TAB: horizontal tab

  • Most important ones to memorize:

    • 32: whitespace
    • 48~57: integer zero to nine
    • 65~90: capital letter A to Z
    • 97~122: lower letter a to z
Sanity Check: assert statement

  • An assertion states a condition that should be true if the program is running properly. If the condition of an assertion evaluates to be false, the program is terminated with a message containing the expression that triggered the assertion failure.

  • Example: non-negative square root function

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    3
    1
    int sqrt(int x) {
    2
        assert(("Argument of sqrt cannot be negative", x >= 0));
    3
    }
    • The entire expression consists of both the "assertion-failure" message and the "condition-to-test" expression. The value of the expression, however, is either 1 or 0, which is the value of the boolean expression x >= 0.
    • As an extra note, the additional set of parentheses is to prevent C from thinking we are trying to pass two arguments assert.
scanf
  • Instead of pass in the variable name (x), we need to pass in the variable's address so scanf would know where to store the input value (&x): scanf("%d", &x);
  • Like printf, the function scanf also returns an integer value --- the number of arguments that were successfully populated. Thus, if the input does not match the format string given to scanf, it can tell us how much data we managed to receive successfully before the program crashes.

Elementary Mutation: Direct Mutation using set!

Overview

  • Elementary mutation uses set! to mutate a name-value binding.

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    5
    1
    > (define x 3)
    2
    > x
    3
    3
    4
    > (set! x 4)
    5
    4
    • model: evaluating a set! expression will change a definition in .

  • Example: Address Book

 
xxxxxxxxxx
3
1
(define address-book empty)
2
(define (add name number)
3
  (set! address-book (cons (list name number) address-book)))

 

Extra Remark on Racket Lists

  • Form I - Immediate Value List: '(a b c 1 2 3)

    • This is a list containing three letters a, b, and c and three numbers 1, 2, and 3.
    • Everything in the list of this form is an immediate value (number or symbol).

  • Form II - Variable Value List: (list a b c 1 2 3)

    • This is a list containing three variables, a, b, and c and three numbers 1, 2, and 3; any one of the variables being undefined would cause an error.
    • Everything in the list of this form is either a number or a variable.

  • Form III - Hybrid List: `(a b ,c 1 2 3)

    • This is a list containing two letters, a and b, one variable, c, and three numbers 1, 2, and 3. Note that the comma before c tells Racket that we are using the value of c instead of the letter c.
    • The ids are treated differently: if there is a comma in front of the id, Racket would evaluate that id and retrieve a value; otherwise, the id is used as an immediate value (symbol).

 

Memoization

  • Caching: a computation is done once and the result gets saved in case the same expression is evaluated again. When several results are saved in a list or table, the process is called memoization.

  • Example: Fibonacci

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    23
    1
    ;; naive implementation
    2
    (define (fib n)
    3
      (cond
    4
       [(= n 0) 0]
    5
       [(= n 1) 1]
    6
       [else (+ (fib (- n 1)) (fib (- n 2)))]))
    7
    ​
    8
    ;; with memoization
    9
    (define (memo-fib n)
    10
      (define fib-table empty) ;; used to store values
    11
      (define result (assoc n fib-table)) ;; either a pair or #f
    12
      (define (fib n) ;; actual function
    13
        (cond
    14
         [(= n 0) 0]
    15
         [(= n 1) 1]
    16
         [else (+ (memo-fib (- n 1)) (memo-fib (- n 2)))]))
    17
      (cond
    18
       [(list? result) (second result)]
    19
       [else 
    20
        (begin
    21
         (define fib-n (fib n))
    22
         (set! fib-table (cons (list n (fib n)) fib-table))
    23
         fib-n)]))
    • (assoc v lst [is-equal?]): a lookup function on a list of pairs; locates the first appearance in a list whose car equals the v according to is-equal?. If element exists, the pair is returned. Otherwise, it returns false.

Intermediate Mutation: Mutate using Boxes/Memory

Boxes in Racket

Motivation: A Failed Mutation
 
xxxxxxxxxx
4
1
(define work '(("Harold" 9172857362)))
2
(define home '())
3
(define (add-entry book name number)
4
  (set! book (cons (list name number) book)))
 
xxxxxxxxxx
4
1
> (add-entry home "Reese" 9172874677) 
2
> home
3
;; expected: '(("Reese" 9172874677))
4
;; reality: '(), an empty list
  • Explanation: book is reduced to '() after reduction; use set! on '() is not a good idea.
Box

  • A struct with one field that supports two operations: get and set.

  • Implementation:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    8
    1
    (define (get b) (b 'get))
    2
    (define (set b v) ((b 'set) v))
    3
    (define (make-box v)
    4
      (define val v)
    5
      (λ (msg)
    6
         (cond
    7
          [(equal? msg 'get) val]
    8
          [(equal? msg 'set) (λ (new_val) (set! val new_val))]))))
Modified Substitution Model
 
xxxxxxxxxx
3
1
exp = (box exp) ;; creating a box
2
    | (unbox id) ;; get request, unboxing a box
3
    | (set-box! exp exp) ;; set request, mutating (the value of) a box
Solution to the Previous Example
 
xxxxxxxxxx
3
1
(define home (box '()))
2
(define (add-entry book name number)
3
  (set-box! book (cons (list name number) (unbox book))))  
Conclusion

  • Rather than working with name-value mapping from CS 145, we now have two mappings:

    • name-location: the box is mapped to a location.
    • location-value: at this location the box's value is stored.

  • When we mutate a box, we change the location-value pair (store different values at the location); the name-location pair remains the same.

  • When we unbox a box, we would check the location first, then retrieve the value stored at the given location.

 

Boxes in C

Call-by-value
  • Both Racket and C use a mechanism known as call-by-value. With this approach, the value that a function receives as its parameter is a copy of the argument rather than the argument itself.
  • Recall that a box containing v is not v itself; it provides us a mean of accessing v (by unboxing the box). In some sense, the box tells us how to find a particular value. In C, we work with addresses and pointers.
Example: add_one and swap
 
xxxxxxxxxx
20
1

2
    int x = 1;
3
    add_one(&x); // passing in x's address
4
    printf("%d\n", x);
5
}

Advanced Mutation: Mutable Structures (not very interesting)

Advanced Mutation in Racket

  • Advanced mutation features in Racket include mutable structures and list.

  • Difference between standard Scheme and Racket:

    • cons fields are mutable with set-car! and set-cdr! in standard Scheme.
    • (normal) cons fields are immutable in Racket; Racket provides a separate data type for mutable pairs -- mcons, which can be mutated using set-mcar! and set-mcdr!.
    • As for structures, struct and define-struct accept the keyword #:mutable, which indicates that the fields of the given structure are mutable.

 

Aliasing in C

 
xxxxxxxxxx
8
1

2

3

4

5

6
    *z = 3; // mutate x's value again
7
    printf("%d %d %d\n", x, *y, *z); // 3 3 3
8
}
  • This phenomenon, in which the same data can be known by multiple names, is known as aliasing.
 
xxxxxxxxxx

Vector in Racket vs. Array in C

Vector vs. Array

Array
  • Type is fixed: every element must be of the same type. Thus every element in the array occupies the same amount of memory.
  • Length is fixed: the length of the array is chosen by the programmer when it is created.
Vector
  • Type is not fixed: a vector can contain unbounded values of various types (one of the "lies" told by Racket).
  • Length is fixed: same as arrays in C, the length of a vector is declared at construction.

 

Vector in Racket

Built-in Functions

  • Create a vector with specified values

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    1
    1
    (define x (vector 'blue true "you" a))

  • Create a vector with a longer length

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    1
    1
    (define x (make-vector 100)) ;; length 100

  • Build a vector with some predefined rules

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    1
    1
    (define x (build-vector 100 sqr))

  • Extract the value at index i of vector x

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    1
    1
    (define v (vector-ref x i))

  • Mutate the value at index i of vector x

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    1
    1
    (vector-set! x i)

Arrays in C

  • An array is a sequence of consecutive memory locations.
Declaration

  • Declare an array: int numbers [6];

  • Declare and initialize: int numbers [] = {0, 0, 1, 0, 0, 0};

    • If the dimension (size) is specified but not all elements in the array are initialized, the remaining elements will contain a value of 0: int numbers[2000] = {245};
    • To initialize an array to all zeros: int numbers [6] = {0};
Usage

  • Extract value: int y = numbers[3];

    • An out-of-bounds array access does not always cause a run time error.

  • Find out the size of the array: int s = sizeof(numbers)/sizeof(int);

    • The sizeof operator produces the number of bytes an item of data occupies in the memory; it is executed by the compiler rather than at run time -- at compile time, the compiler substitutes the actual size of the item in place of the sizeof expression.
Name of an Array

  • The name of an array is a shorthand for a pointer to its first element.

    • int myArray[100]: myArray is a shorthand for &myArray[0] (i.e. the address of the first element of myArray).
Array Index

  • Let t be a type and consider t arr[10].

    • sizeof(arr) equals 10 * sizeof(t).
    • arr is a shorthand for &arr[0], i.e. *arr is equivalent to arr[0].
    • arr+1 is a shorthand for &arr[1].
    • In general, arr+k produces the address equals to arr+k*sizeof(t).
    • Thus *(arr+k) means arr[k].

  • As a conclusion, any pointer may be though of as pointing to the beginning of an array, and the syntax for accessing an array item through a pointer is identical to the syntax for accessing an item via an array.

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    8
    1
    int sum (int *arr, int size) {
    2
        int res = 0;
    3
        for (int *cur = arr; // cur points to *arr
    4
             cur < arr + size; // stop condition
    5
             ++cur) // move onto the next item
    6
            res += *cur; // *cur points to an element in the array
    7
        return res;
    8
    }
Array vs. Pointer
  • On a machine where int occupies four bytes and address occupy eight bytes, an integer array of length 10 occupies bytes where the pointer stores an address which occupies 8 bytes.

Memory Management

Memory Model

Stack

  • Each function call allocates a portion of the stack, known as a stack frame, which holds the function call's local variables and return address.

  • Each function call gets its own frame, thus each function call get its own copy of the function's local variables.

  • When a function returns, its stack frame is popped and all local variables in the frame are released. This is achieved by the use of a stack pointer: a variable which keeps track of the location of the top of the previous stack frame; the old stack frame still typically persists but will be overwritten by a new frame the next time a function is called.

  • Dangling pointers: pointers pointing to dead memory.

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    7
    1
    struct Posn makePosn (int x, int y) {
    2
        struct Posn p;
    3
        int a = x, b = y; // local variables on stack 
    4
        p.x = &a;
    5
        p.y = &b;
    6
        return p;
    7
    }
    • When the function returns, local variables a and b are released; pointers p.x and p.y are thus pointing to dead memory.
    • Never return a pointer to data stored on local stack. If a function is to return a pointer, the pointer should point to either static, heap, or non-local stack data.
Heap

  • The function malloc requests memory from the heap, which is essentially a pool of memory, from which you may explicitly request contiguous portions. While stack memory has a life time that ends with the function that allocate it, heap memory can have an arbitrarily long life time.

  • Garbage collector

    • A garbage collector reclaims memory that is no longer accessible, meaning there exists no valid pointers pointing to that memory anymore.
    • A garbage collector may make the language easier to work with as the programmer doesn't need to worry about the memory-freeing process, however this means that programmers have no control over the management of memory.

  • To free memory in C, we need to explicitly call free function.

    • Good habit: after calling free(p), assign p to NULL, a location that is guaranteed to be invalid.
    • As a remark, if a call to malloc fails, a null pointer is returned.

  • When to use heap?

    • For data that should outlive the function that created it.

    • For data whose size is not known at compile-time or has the potential to grow.

       
      xxxxxxxxxx
      4
      1
      int size;
      2
      scanf("%d", &size);
      3
      int *p = malloc(size * sizeof(int));
      4
      free(p); // to free an array

    • For large local arrays.

Function Pointers

Motivation

  • C's declaration syntax follows the peculiar logic that the way a variable is declared echoes the way the variable will be used.

    • For example, a pointer definition like int *p asserts that p is a pointer, but if we read the definition in the way it is intended, we see that it actually says *p is an int, implying that p must be a pointer. Hence, p's identity as a pointer is conveyed by the way in which p is used in the definition.

  • Function pointers are useful for passing functions as parameters to other function. In other words, it gives C pseudo first-class functionality.

Function Pointers in C

  • Suppose we have a function which we will be pointing to:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    1
    1
    int addInt(int n, int m) { return n+m; }

  • First thing, we want to define a pointer to a function which receives two ints and returns an int:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    1
    1
    int (*functionPtr) (int,int);

  • Now we have two ways to make functionPtr point to our function addInt:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    1
    1
    functionPtr = &addInt; // let functionPtr store the address of addInt
     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    1
    1
    functionPtr = addInt; // also valid since the standard says that a function name in this context is conveyed to the address of the function

  • To use our function, we can do 

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    1
    1
    int sum = (*functionPtr)(2, 3); // sum <- 5

  • Passing the pointer to another function is the same:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    4
    1
    // Note that the function add2to3 accepts only one function pointer as argument; the function being pointed to by this pointer is later applied to 2 and 3.
    2
    int add2to3(int (*functionPtr)(int, int)) {
    3
        return (*functionPtr)(2,3);
    4
    }

  • Use a typedef to clean things up:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    6
    1
    typedef int (*int_int_to_int)(int,int);
    2
    int_int_to_int functionFactory(int n) {
    3
        printf("Got parameter %d", n);
    4
        int_int_to_int functionPtr = &addInt;
    5
        return functionPtr;
    6
    }
General Pattern
  • Suppose you have a function pointer fptr pointing to a function, which has return type return_type and consumes two arguments of type arg_type_one and arg_type_two:
 
xxxxxxxxxx

5

7
    fp(arg_one, arg_two); // apply the function

    ...

Remarks on Compilation and Linking

  1. Never compile .h files: header files are compiled when they are included into .c files.

  2. To do these two stages separately:

    • gcc -c sequence .c: create sequence.o
    • gcc -c main.c: create main.o
    • gcc sequence.o main.o -o myprogram: link them together and output an executable myprogram
Remarks on Implementation
  1. We defined a new type SeqImpl which is an alias to *Sequence, pointers to Sequence.
  2. We take advantage of the fact that pointers, no matter what they point at, all have the same size.
  3. A function or file-scope variable declared static may only be accessed from within the file in which it is defined. Also, because they are not globally accessible, we an write static functions with the same name, as long as they reside in different files.

 

Amortized Analysis

Motivation

  • Consider what happens over a sequence of calls to add:

    • The first inserts cost
    • The next insert costs since we copied the entire array; cap becomes
    • The next inserts cost
    • The next insert costs ; cap becomes
    • The next inserts cost
    • The next insert costs ; cap becomes
    • ...

  • Total cost:

  • Total operation:

Amortized Analysis
  • Although individual operations may be costly, they are "paid for" by a prior sequence of inexpensive operations, so that the cost of any sequence of operations, and therefore the cost per operation, is small.
  • We say that with a strategy that doubles the capacity, add runs in amortized time.

Module 2~4: SIMP, PRIMP, MMIX

SIMP: A Simple Imperative Language

This module discusses an artificial imperative language that has enough features to be able to illustrate concepts and difficulties that arise, while being simple enough to facilitate precise specification an implementation in the manner we are used to from CS 145.

Syntax and Informal Semantics

Overview
  • A SIMP program consists of declaration and initialization of some variables to integer values, followed by one or more statements.
  • I suffer way too much PTSD from the Q8 and Q9 the SIMP->A-PRIMP compiler.

Sample Program 2: Computing Perfect Numbers (Brute Force)
  • A number is perfect if its divisors (including 1 but excluding itself) add up to it.

                   (print i)

                   (print "\n"))
14
                  (skip))
15
             (set i (+ i 1))))

Proving Imperative Programs Correct: Hoare Logic

Hoare Triples
  • We want to prove triples of the form {P}statement{Q} where P and Q are parameterized logical statements: "if precondition P is true in the initial state, and statement is executed, then postcondition Q will be true in the final state."
  • More precisely, we are proving "for all states is true, and the executing of statement starting in state results in state , then is true."
Proving SIMP Statements to be True

  • General case: the entire program

    • To conclude {P}(vars ([x1 v1] ... [xi vi]) stmt ...){Q},
    • It suffices to show {P and x1-v1 and ... and x-v-}(seq stmt ...){Q}.

  • seq: sequences of statements

    • To conclude {P}(seq stmt1 stmt2){Q},

    • If suffices to show {P}stmt1{R} and {R}stmt2{Q} (finding {R} can be tricky).

      • Technique: strengthen a precondition and/or weaken a postcondition:

        • To conclude {P'}stmt{Q'},

        • We show the following

          1. {P}stmt{Q}
          2. P' P
          3. Q Q'

  • set: mutation (tricky)

    • To conclude {P}(set x exp){Q},

    • It suffices to show {Q [exp/x]}(set x exp){Q}

      • {Q [exp/x]}: Q with exp replaced by x
      • The states before and after the execution of the set differ only in the value of x, so anything that Q says about other variables is true before the set is executed. Furthermore, if Q says something about x, then that must be true of exp before the set is executed.
      • This seems like a backward strategy -- for Q to be true after the mutation, Q must be true before the mutation with x being replaced by exp.

  • iif: if statement

    • To conclude {P}(iif B stmt1 stmt2){Q}
    • It suffices to show {P and B}stmt1{Q} and {P and not B}stmt2{Q}.

  • while: while loop (trickiest)

    • To conclude {P}(while B stmt ...){Q}

      • If the loop doesn't run: {P}(while B stmt ...){P}
      • At the end off the loop, B must be false: {P}(while B stmt ...){P and not B}
      • If the loop repeats and runs more than once, whatever was true at the end of the loop body remains to be true at the beginning of the loop (as we enter the next iteration) and B needs to be true as well: {P and B}(seq s1 ... sn){P}

    • We see that P is preserved by the body of the loop. We call P the loop invariant.

Example: Proving Fibonacci Program is True

  • Let F(n) denote the nth Fibonacci number. In the program below, we are trying to find the 10th Fibonacci number.

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    6
    1
    (vars [(n 10)(fj 1)(fjm1 0)(t 0)]
    2
            (while (not (= n 1))
    3
                  (set t fj)
    4
                   (set fj (+ fj fjm1))
    5
                   (set fjm1 t)
    6
                (set n (- n 1))))

  • We shall start from the end. The postcondition fj = F(10) represents our goal; we also use the fact that we know all the initial values of the variables:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    8
    1
    (vars [(n 10)(fj 1)(fjm1 0)(t 0)]
    2
          ;; n = 10, fj = F(1), fjm1 = F(0)
    3
          (while (not (= n 1))
    4
                 (set t fj)
    5
                 (set fj (+ fj fjm1))
    6
                 (set fjm1 t)
    7
                (set n (- n 1))))
    8
                ;; fj = F(10)

  • We need to find a loop invariant, which in this case is fj = F(11-n) and fjm1 = F(10-n):

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    10
    1
    (vars [(n 10)(fj 1)(fjm1 0)(t 0)]
    2
          ;; n = 10, fj = F(1), fjm1 = F(0)
    3
          ;; fj = F(11-n), fjm1 = F(10-n) => this is P
    4
          (while (not (= n 1))
    5
                 (set t fj)
    6
                 (set fj (+ fj fjm1))
    7
                 (set fjm1 t)
    8
                (set n (- n 1))))
    9
                ;; fj = F(11-n), fjm1 = F(10-n), n=1 => P and not B
    10
                ;; fj = F(10)

  • Now go into the while loop. Because the body of the seq consists of a series of set statements and because the proof for each one involves a precondition that is a modification of the postcondition, the proof proceeds by pushing the postcondition for the seq back through the set statements, modifying it appropriately, and showing that the precondition for the seq is achieved.

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    7
    1
    ;; fj = F(11-n), fjm1 = F(10-n), not n = 1 => at the beginning of the loop we have P and B
    2
    (seq
    3
     (set t fj)
    4
     (set fj (+ fj fjm1))
    5
     (set fjm1 t)
    6
     (set n (- n 1)))
    7
    ;; fj = F(11-n), fjn1 = F(10-n) ;; we won't have B here tho, since this is the end of one iteration.

  • Start with the final postcondition

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    6
    1
    (seq 
    2
     (set t fj)
    3
     (set fj (+ fj fjm1))
    4
     (set fjm1 t)
    5
     (set n (- n 1)))
    6
    ;; fj = F(11-n), fjm1 = F(10-n)

  • Pushing the postcondition through the last set statement involves replacing n-1 with n everywhere in the postcondition:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    8
    1
    (seq 
    2
     (set t fj)
    3
     (set fj (+ fj fjm1))
    4
     (set fjm1 t)
    5
    ;; fj = F(11-(n-1)), fjm1 = F(10-(n-1)) ;; n is replaced by n-1
    6
    ;; => fj = F(12-n), fjm1 = F(11-n)
    7
     (set n (- n 1)))
    8
    ;; fj = F(11-n), fjm1 = F(10-n)

  • Continue this process: 

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    11
    1
    ;; fj+fjm1 = F(12-n), fj = F(11-n) => precondition after derivation
    2
    (seq 
    3
    ;; fj+fjm1 = F(12-n), fj = F(11-n) ;; replace t by fj
    4
     (set t fj)
    5
    ;; fj+fjm1 = F(12-n), t = F(11-n) ;; replace fj by (+ fj fjm1)
    6
     (set fj (+ fj fjm1))
    7
    ;; fj = F(12-n), t = F(11-n) ;; replace fjm1 by 1
    8
     (set fjm1 t) 
    9
    ;; fj = F(12-n), fjm1 = F(11-n) : replace n by n-1
    10
     (set n (- n 1))) 
    11
    ;; fj = F(11-n), fjm1 = F(10-n)

  • Strengthen the precondition:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    12
    1
    ;; fj = F(11-n), fjm1 = F(10-n), not n = 1
    2
    ;; fj+fjm1 = F(12-n), fj = F(11-n) => precondition after derivation
    3
    (seq 
    4
    ;; fj+fjm1 = F(12-n), fj = F(11-n) ;; replace t by fj
    5
     (set t fj)
    6
    ;; fj+fjm1 = F(12-n), t = F(11-n) ;; replace fj by (+ fj fjm1)
    7
     (set fj (+ fj fjm1))
    8
    ;; fj = F(12-n), t = F(11-n) ;; replace fjm1 by 1
    9
     (set fjm1 t) 
    10
    ;; fj = F(12-n), fjm1 = F(11-n) : replace n by n-1
    11
     (set n (- n 1))) 
    12
    ;; fj = F(11-n), fjm1 = F(10-n)
    • Since n != 1, we always have fj + fjm1 = F(12-n) given fj = F(11-n) and fjm1 = F(10-n).

PRIMP: A Primitive Imperative Language

PRIMP Machine Language, A-PRIMP Assembly Language, Assembler from A-PRIMP to PRIMP, Compiler from SIMP to A_PRIMP, Variation of SIMP

A Primitive Imperative Language

PRIMP Memory

  • Main data structure: vector

    • Advantage: constant-time access to any element.
    • Disadvantage: fixed size and lack the flexibility of lists (can't use rest to progress into the sequence of statements).
Program Counter (PC)
  • The sequence will remain fixed and unchanged throughout the computation.
  • Program counter: a Racket variable holding the index (location) of the next instruction to be executed.
Fetch-execute Cycle

  • The simulator repeats the following actions:

    • Fetch the instruction at the location indexed by PC
    • Increment PC (so that the next instruction is the next one to be fetched)
    • Execute the fetched statement
Variables and Statements
  • PRIMP will no longer have named variables. Each integer variable will be stored in one element of PRIMP memory. We shall use memory locations that right after the ones that used to store the program. At this point, we will not limit the range of an integer value; variables can hold unbounded values.
  • However, we break complicated nested statements from SIMP into a sequence of simple statements so that each PRIMP statement takes up constant space.
Notation

  • Immediate operand (representing an integer or boolean value)

    • 2: refers to the number 2

  • Indirect operand (representing the value stored at address)

    • (2): refers to the PRIMP memory location of index 2
Arithmetic Operations

  • Two operands and one destination.

  • Examples

    • (add (5) (1) (2)) :
    • (add (7) (7) 1) :

  • Arithmetic operators: add sub mul div mod

Comparison/Logical Operations
  • Two operands and one destination (except for lnot)
  • Comparison operators: equal not-equal gt ge lt le
  • Logical operators: land lor lnot
Other Statements

  • Copy information from one location to another.

    • (move (10) (12)) :

  • Unconditional jump.

    • (jump 12) :

  • Conditional branch.

    • (branch (20) 12) : if then

  • Print function for immediate constants or contents of memory locations.

    • (print-val 21)

  • Print function for strings.

    • (print-string "\n")
Other Remarks
  • A program is a sequence of instructions and Racket values.
  • Execution starts with the instruction at index zero.
  • The program halts on the first attempt to fetch and execute a non-instruction (an integer or Boolean values, as all instructions are lists).

Complete PRIMP Instruction Set

  • opd: can be either an immediate operand, an indirect operand, or an offset.
  • dest: destination, which can be either an indirect operand or an offset.
  • imm: just for readability purpose; an immediate value can be either an integer or a boolean.
  • ind: indirect value, which is a natural number wrapped inside a pair of parentheses.

Motivation
  • Writing a PRIMP program is both awkward and time-consuming. To make this process easier, we can either write a compiler while translates a SIMP program to a PRIMP program, or an assembler that provides a few useful features for writing PRIMP. Examples of useful features include variable-like names for memory locations and constants, and labels for the target of jump and branch operations.

The A-PRIMP to PRIMP Assembler

A-PRIMP Language

  • A-PRIMP adds some pseudo-instructions to PRIMP:

    • (lit 4) : literal 4, for readability.

    • (halt) : produces 0, for readability.

    • (const VAR 6) : declares the symbol NAME to have value 6.

      • VAR here can be used as an immediate value.

    • (label LOC) : bounds NAME to the index of next instruction.

      • LOC here can be used as target for jump and branch
      • Note that LOC is actually a number (index number, to be precise) instead of an address

    • (data PTR 1 2 3 4) : declares an array, NAME has the value of the index where the first element (i.e. 1) is stored; 2, 3, and 4 are stored in consecutive memory locations following the first one.

      • PTR here can be used an indirect value.

    • (data NAME (5 1) : equivalent to (data NAME 1 1 1 1 1).

    • (data X 1) (data Y X) : symbol defined using data can also be used as an immediate operand in a data statement.

      • Direct translation: 1 50

      • Values

        • X : 50
        • (X): 1
        • Y: 51
        • (Y): X = 50

      • That is, when we do (data PTR val), PTR's value is the index, dereferencing PTR gives us the value it points to.

A-PRIMP Additional Grammar Rules for Pseudo-instructions
 
xxxxxxxxxx
6
1
stmt = (halt)
2
     | (lit psymbol-or-value)
3
     | (const psymbol psymbol-or-value)
4
     | (data psymbol psymbol-or-value ...)
5
     | (data psymbol (nat psymbol-or-value))
6
     | (label psymbol)
  • A psymbol defined in a const pseudo-instruction can be used as an immediate PRIMP operand, and a psymbol defined in a data pseudo-instruction can be used as an indirect PRIMP operand or an immediate value in data and const pseudo-instructions.
Assembler
  • The assembler operates in two phases.
  • First phase: set up a hash table which maps symbol to values.
  • Second phase: resolve the mapping so that symbols are substituted by their values.
Possible Errors
  • "circular": the code contains a chain of circular references
  • "duplicate": the code contains a duplicate psymbol
  • "undefined": the code contains an undefined psymbol
  • "incorrect": the code uses a psymbol incorrectly
Technical Details

  • Hash table

    • `(const ,n ,v): key = n, value = v
    • `(data ,n ,v ...): key = n, value = current index
    • `(label ,n): key = n, value = current index

  • Incrementing index counter

    • We need to keep track of the index (line number) since both data and label uses the index as value in hash table.
    • Since const, data and label statements don't exist in PRIMP, we only need to takes note on the key-value pair; they do not influence the index.
    • Besides these three, all other statements increments index by one.

  • To check for circular and undefined errors

    • General strategy: go through the entire hash table, if a psymbol shows up as a value, we shall resolve this psymbol (by looking it up in the hash table and replace the psymbol by its actual value, if defined).
    • List as accumulator: consider the definition A -> B -> C -> D -> 5, i.e. A is defined to have B's value; B is defined to have C's value, and so on, until D is defined to be 5. The overall effect is that all four variables have a value of 5. To check for circular definition and also update all variables at once, we have an extra list as an accumulator, so that every time we look up a new psymbol, we add the old one to the list; when we reach an immediate value, we know that all variables in the list are valid, so we replace every instance of variables in the list by the value we have just found. However, if we reach a psymbol that has already been inside our list, we can safely say there exists a circular definition and raise an error about it.

The SIMP to A-PRIMP Compiler

Stack Pointer
  • A data statement that reserves a location for the index of the first unused element of the stack.
  • Note that the destination of the move is not known at the time of writing the problem (stored in SP), so we allow an indirect operand as the destination of a move in the definition of PRIMP.
Offset
  • Consider (add (10) (-1 (59)) 1). It has the result .
  • Suppose SP points to 59, i.e. we have `(data SP 200) at line 59.
  • Then (59) = = 200, i.e. the next unused spot is location 200.
  • -1 is an offset from the location that SP points to -- SP points to location 200, subtracting 1 and dereference, we get whatever that's stored at location 199. We then add 1 to this value and save it at location 10.
Working with SP

  • The next unused location: (0 SP)

  • The top element on the stack: (-1 SP)

  • Pushing an element (say, 3) onto the stack: (move (0 SP) 3) (add SP SP 1)

    • We copy 3 to the value pointed to by SP
    • We then increment SP by 1, so SP still points to the next unused location

  • Popping an element from the stack: (sub SP SP 1)

    • The element might still be on the stack; all we need is to subtract SP by 1, so next time a new element begin pushed onto the stack would overwrite the old value.
aexp and bexp

  • Base case: if aexp is a number or symbol or bexp is number, boolean or symbol, we push the value directly onto stack by doing `(move (0 SP) <val>) then increment SP by 1.

  • Recursive case: if aexp or bexp is of the form (,op ,arg1 ,arg2), compute two arguments first (recursion) -- note that, if the program is set up correctly, the result of arg1 will be left at (-2 SP) and the result of arg2 will be left at (-1 SP). Hence we shall replace (-2 SP) by the final result (applying the corresponding operation to (-2 SP) and (-1 SP)): (,(op-trans op) (-2 SP) (-2 SP) (-1 SP)).

    • op-trans is a helper which translates add to +, mul to *, etc.
    • Since and and or can take variable number of arguments, we can do pairwise operations, e.g. apply and to the first two arguments, store the result at (-1 SP), then apply and to (-1 SP) and then update (-1 SP) accordingly.
set statement: `(set ,id ,aexp)
  • Handle aexp first; the answer returned by aexp is left at top of the stack.
  • Now set id to this value by with `(move ,id (-1 SP)) and decrement SP by 1.
iif statement: (iif bexp stmt1 stmt2)

  • The code compiles to

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    9
    1
    bexp-code ;; result at (-1 SP)
    2
    (branch (-1 SP) TRUE)
    3
    (jump FALSE)
    4
    (label TRUE)
    5
    stmt1-code
    6
    (jump DONE)
    7
    (label FALSE)
    8
    stmt2-code
    9
    (label DONE)
while statement: (while bexp stmt1 ...)

  • The code compiles to 

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    8
    1
    (label START)
    2
    bexp-code ;; result at (-1 SP)
    3
    (branch (-1 SP) LOOP)
    4
    (jump DONE)
    5
    (label LOOP)
    6
    stmts-code ;; we need to convert every stmt here
    7
    (jump START)
    8
    (label DONE)
Other Remarks
  • You need to somehow prevent label names from clashing.

Variations of SIMP and PRIMP

SIMP-A: SIMP with Arrays

Sample Program
 
xxxxxxxxxx
6
1
;; SIMP
2
(vars [(sum 0) (i 0) (A (array 1 2 3 4 5))]
3
      (while (< i 5)
4
             (set sum (+ sum (array-ref A i)))
5
             (set i (+ i 1)))
6
      (print sum))
 
xxxxxxxxxx
17
1
;; PRIMP
2
(label LOOP-TOP)
3
(lt TMP I SIZE-A)
4
(branch TMP1 LOOP-CONT)
5
(jump LOOP-DONE)
6
(label LOOP-CONT)
7
(add SUM SUM (A I)) ;; Think about this line
8
(add I I 1)
9
(jump LOOP-TOP)
10
(label LOOP-DONE)
11
(print-val SUM)
12
(halt)
13
(data SUM 0)
14
(data I 0)
15
(data SIZE-A 5)
16
(data TMP1 0)
17
(data A 1 2 3 4 5)
  • (A I) : , which is equivalent to A[i]
  • A: line number, 15
  • (I) : , offset, 0 ~ 4
  • Dereference , we get the desired result.
Array Size

  • To signal an error when an array index is out of bound, we need to add another data statement to keep record of length of the array:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    6
    1
    ;; SIMP:
    2
    (A (array 1 2 3 4 5) 
    3
      
    4
    ;; A-PRIMP:
    5
    (data SIZE_A 5) 
    6
    (data _A 1 2 3 4 5).

  • To construct an array with the same initial value:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    6
    1
    ;; SIMP:
    2
    (A (make-array 5 0))
    3
    ​
    4
    ;; A-PRIMP:
    5
    (data SIZE_A 5)
    6
    (data _A 0 0 0 0 0)
Get Request

  • Suppose we have (array-ref A i) where A is an array and i is the index.

  • We first check if the index is non-negative. We ignore the use of SP for simplicity.

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    2
    1
    (lt TMP0 _i 0) ;; TMP0 <- (_i < 0)
    2
    (branch TMP0 INDEX-ERROR) ;; if so, raise INDEX-ERROR

  • Next, check if the index is greater than or equal to the size of the array.

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    2
    1
    (ge TMP0 _i SIZE_A) ;; TMP0 <- (_i >= SIZE_A)
    2
    (branch TMP0 INDEX-ERROR) ;; if so, raise INDEX-ERROR

  • Finally, we can dereference the target location.

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    1
    1
    (move TMP0 (_A _i))

  • Remark. You can control how run-time error check works.

Set Request

  • Suppose we have (array-set A i j) where A is an array, i is the index and j is the value to use.

  • We first do the same two index checking:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    4
    1
    (lt TMP0 _i 0) ;; TMP0 <- (_i < 0)
    2
    (branch TMP0 INDEX-ERROR) ;; if so, raise INDEX-ERROR
    3
    (ge TMP0 _i SIZE_A) ;; TMP0 <- (_i >= SIZE_A)
    4
    (branch TMP0 INDEX-ERROR) ;; if so, raise INDEX-ERROR

  • Now we set the value 

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    1
    1
    (move (_A _i) _j) ;; copy _j to the location A[i]
Side Remark on C
  • In C, memory addresses (pointers) can be stored in variables. They are not as general as integer variables, but we can do pointer arithmetic and write code that explicitly dereferences a pointer, namely using the value stored in the memory address as an address itself.
  • By making these available to the programmer, C can treat arrays and pointers as interchangeable. This gives programmers more power to manipulate memory directly (which can lead to greater efficiently), but makes it impossible to put general array bounds checking in (which implied reduced safety).

 

SIMP-F: SIMP with Functions

Sample Program
 
xxxxxxxxxx
4
1
(fun (f x y)
2
     (vars ([i 0] [j 10])
3
           (set i (+ (* j x) y))
4
           (return (* i i))))
Overview
  • A program is not a sequence of function definitions.
  • There is a special function called main (defined with no parameters) which is where we start the program.
  • New problem: once the body of the function has been executed, the value must be returned to the code that contained the function application, so the PC at the time the function was applied has to be saved somewhere and later restored. This requires a new instruction.
jsr: Jump to Subroutine

  • The instruction (jsr (50) 10) has the effect .

    • The first operand can be a destination and the second operand can be a target.
    • Note that in the fetch-execute cycle, the PC has already been incremented (in the simulator), so the value saved is the address of the next instruction after jsr, which is the next instruction to be executed after the function has completed execution.
    • To return to where we were, we would jump back using (jump (50)), which has meaning .
Stack Frame
  • A memory management strategy used to create and destroy temporary variables. It allows recursive calling of subroutines. Stack Frames only exist at run-time.
  • Each stack frame contains space for actual parameters (arguments), local variables (defined using vars), previous frame pointer and and previous PC. This space is allocated dynamically (at run time) rather than statically.
  • When the function call finishes executing, its stack frame is popped from the stack and thread execution resumes back in the calling procedure.
  • To allocate a stack frame, move the stack pointer by adding the amount of fixed space needed at the stop of the stack frame to it. To deallocate a stack frame, subtract this amount from the stack pointer.
Three Pointers
  • Stack Pointer: pointing to the "top" of the stack
  • Frame Pointer: pointing to the "top" of the frame
  • PC: pointing to the next instruction to be executed
Procedure to Enter a Function Call
  • "Save current": The caller saves local variables and temporaries by pushing them onto the stack.
  • "Push argument": The caller pushes the callee's actual parameters onto the stack.
  • "jsr": The caller branches to the callee, pushing PC onto the stack; the saved PC is called the return address.
  • "Save FP": The caller pushes the value of FP onto the stack.
  • "Update FP": The callee copies SP to FP.
  • "Update SP": The callee adjusts SP, creating storage locations for local variables and local temporaries on the stack.
Remark on Entering a Function Call
  1. Steps 4~6 above are referred to as the function prologue, since they are the beginning of every function.
  2. Within the body of the callee function, formal arguments and local variables can all be access at an address relative to the FP. Because of this, a function may recurse and automatically create a different storage location for each of its local variables.
Procedure to Exit a Function Call
  • "Restore SP": The callee restores SP, and in doing so destroys the storage location reserved for locals and temporaries.
  • "Restore FP": The callee restores FP, and in doing so returns to the previous frame.
  • "Restore PC": The callee branches back to caller by restoring PC (popping PC from the stack).
  • "Remove Arguments": The caller removes the actual parameters from the stack.
  • "Restore Current": The caller restores local variables and temporaries by popping them from the stack.
Remark on Exiting a Function Call
  1. Steps 1~3 above are referred to as the function epilogue, since they are at the end of every function.

 

SIMP-FAC: SIMP with Functions and C-Style Arrays

Motivation
  • We can declare arrays to be local function variables which are stored on the stack. If a function produce a pointer into such an array and that pointer later gets used to access the stack space that the array formerly occupied, we have a dangling pointer.
  • To add both functions and Racket-style arrays (i.e. with bounds checking but without pointer arithmetic), we need to combine the SIMP-A idea of storing the array size with the idea of an extra level of indirection between the name of an array and its contents.
Example

  • Say we have (A (make-array 5 0))

  • We now need three data statements:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    3
    1
    (data _A CONTENTS_A)        ;; at line 500
    2
    (data SIZE_A 5)             ;; at line 501
    3
    (data CONTENTS_A 0 0 0 0 0) ;; at line 502

  • If we pass the array A as an argument to a function that has an array parameter P, then the value assigned to P will be 502.

  • We can use similar bound-checking mechanisms we used in SIMP-A.

 

PRIMP with Lists

Possible Implementation of List in PRIMP

  • A cons can be two consecutive memory locations; the first contains a number and the second an address (pointer to the next element).

  • Goal: [6, 4, 3]

  • Possible implementation: 

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    4
    1
    (const EMPTY 0)
    2
    (data NODE3 6 NODE2)
    3
    (data NODE2 4 NODE1)
    4
    (data NODE1 3 EMPTY)
    • Convention: 0 is not a valid address for data.
    • The order and position of data statements is not important -- flexibility of lists.
Coding Example: Computing Sum of a List

  • Code

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    9
    1
    (move P LIST)        ;; LIST: address, head of the list
    2
    (move SUM 0)         ;; initialize a variable
    3
    (label LOOP)         ;; while loop start label
    4
    (eq TMP0 P EMPTY)    ;; condition: test if P is empty
    5
    (branch TMP0 DONE)   ;; if P is empty, end loop
    6
    (add SUM SUM P)      ;; update sum
    7
    (move P (1 P))       ;; IMPORTANT: see remarks below
    8
    (jump LOOP)          ;; re-enter the loop
    9
    (label DONE)         ;; done

  • Stepper

    • Recall the grammar rule:

    • Suppose our current (A-PRIMP) code looks like

       
      xxxxxxxxxx
      9
      1
      (const EMPTY 0)      ;; line 0: EMPTY = 0
      2
      (data LIST  6 NODE2) ;; line 1: LIST  = 1, (LIST)  = 6
      3
                           ;; line 2: NODE2
      4
      (data NODE2 4 NODE1) ;; line 3: NODE2 = 3, (NODE2) = 4
      5
                           ;; line 4: NODE1
      6
      (data NODE1 3 EMPTY) ;; line 5: NODE1 = 5, (NODE1) = 3
      7
                           ;; line 6: EMPTY
      8
      (data P 0)           ;; line 7: index variable
      9
      (data TMP0 0)        ;; line 8: temp variable

    • Stepper

       
      xxxxxxxxxx
      25
      1
      (move P LIST)           : M[P] <- M[LIST], P = 1, (P) = 6
      2
      (move SUM 0)            : SUM = 0
      3
      (label LOOP)    
      4
      ;; first iteration
      5
      (eq TMP0 P EMPTY)       : TMP0 <- (P == EMPTY), TMP0 = 0
      6
      (branch TMP0 DONE)      : Not executed
      7
      (add SUM SUM P)         : P is an indirect operand which points to 6 => SUM = 6
      8
      (move P (1 P))          : P <- 1 + P, P = NODE2 = 3, (P) = 4
      9
      (jump LOOP)   
      10
      ;; second iteration
      11
      (eq TMP0 P EMPTY)       : TMP0 <- (P == EMPTY), TMP0 = 0
      12
      (branch TMP0 DONE)      : Not executed
      13
      (add SUM SUM P)         : (P) = 4 => SUM = 6 + 4 = 10
      14
      (move P (1 P))          : P <- 1 + P, P = NODE1 = 5, (P) = 3
      15
      (jump LOOP)   
      16
      ;; third iteration
      17
      (eq TMP0 P EMPTY)       : TMP0 <- (P == EMPTY), TMP0 = 0
      18
      (branch TMP0 DONE)      : Not executed
      19
      (add SUM SUM P)         : (P) = 3 => SUM = 10 + 3 = 13
      20
      (move P (1 P))          : P <- 1 + P, P = EMPTY = 0, (P) DNE
      21
      (jump LOOP)             
      22
      ;; four iteration
      23
      (eq TMP0 P EMPTY)       : TMP0 <- (P == EMPTY), TMP0 = 1
      24
      (branch TMP0 DONE)      : Executed
      25
      (label DONE)            : Exit Loop
