Creating Lists at Run-time

  • Strategy I: free list (initially empty)

    • When a cons cell is not needed anymore, we add it to the free list.
    • If we need a new cell, we first look at this free list and see if any cell is available.
    • If not, we allocate new cells from unused memory.

  • Strategy II: garbage collection (automatic)

Indicate Types

  • To allow lists contain elements of various types, we could represent a cons cell by three memory locations instead of two; the additional location holds a type tag for the value field.

  • Possible Implementation:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    6
    1
    (const INT-TYPE 0)
    2
    (const CONS-TYPE 1)
    3
    (data NODE2 CONS-TYPE NODE3 NODE1)
    4
    (data NODE1 INT-TYPE 3 EMPTY)
    5
    (data NODE3 INT-TYPE 2 NODE4)
    6
    (data NODE4 INT-TYPE 1 EMPTY)

Strings in C

Overview

  • C does not have a build-in string type; a string in C are represented by an array of characters.

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    1
    1
    char myString[] = "hello";

  • Similar to other arrays, the contents of this string reside on the stack.

Null-terminated

  • Each C string ends with a null character (ASCII 0) whose purpose is to signal the end of the string. Thus, we allocating space for strings, we must remember to include one extra character to hold the null terminator. 

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    1
    1
    char myString[] = "Hello"; // 'H', 'e', 'l', 'l', 'o', '\0'
    • The array holds six characters instead of five because of the implicit null terminator.

  • To print a string, printf("%s", myString); will keep printing characters from myString until it encounters the null terminator. Note that the null character itself is not printed. If for some reason the null terminator is missing, the program will keep printing until either it reaches another \0 or it reaches the end of accessible memory (and most likely will crash).

Difference between Pointer and Arrays, Revisit

  • Different sizes: suppose we have two definitions

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    9
    1
    int main() {
    2
        char string[] = {'H','e','l','l','o'};
    3
        char myString[] = "Hello";
    4
        char *yourString = "Hello";
    5
        
    6
        printf("%zd", sizeof(string));     // 5
    7
        printf("%zd", sizeof(myString));   // 6
    8
        printf("%zd", sizeof(yourString)); // 8
    9
    }
    • First thing first, you need to be familiar with the storage size of common types in C (rip I literally forgot that each char takes up one byte which left me super confused for five minutes writing this part) -- each char takes one byte and each int takes 4 bytes; each pointer takes 8 bytes, etc.
    • sizeof(string): this is an array of five char each takes 1 byte, thus in total consumes 5 bytes.
    • sizeof(myString): there is an implicit null terminator, thus in total consumes 6 bytes.
    • sizeof(yourString): this is a pointer and pointers of any type always consume 8 bytes.

  • Different memory location: 

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    2
    1
    myString[0] = 'h'; // valid code, mutate an array entry
    2
    yourString[0] = 'h'; // undefined behavior, most likely will crash

    • Question: where in memory does the string literal "Hello" that was used to initialize yourString reside? In other words, where does the pointer yourString point to?

      • Not heap: we didn't use malloc
      • Not stack: otherwise the program should be fine
      • This leaves either the static area or the code area.

    • Answer: string literals and constant values are typically held in an area called the literal pool (somewhere in the static segment or the code segment, doesn't really matter), which is typically placed within read-only memory, so that any attempt to modify a literal pool string will likely fail.

    • Reason: by placing string literals in read-only memory, the compiler is able to save space by using the same location for string literals that appear multiple times.

      • For example, multiple use of string literal "%d\n" will most likely point to the same location.
      • Fun remark: if this does not reside in read-only memory, the assignment (mutation) of one would affect all three literals and effectively destroy the program. The use of read-only memory prevents this possibility.

    • Lesson: it may make sense to declare the pointer constant: const char *ptr = "Hello";

const and Pointers

  • When combining const with pointers, are we making the pointer constant or the data it points to constant? The answer depends on where the keyword const occurs.

  • There are three possible situations (we omit the nested pointer case):

    • non-constant pointer to a constant: const int *ptr = 1

      • The pointer itself is not constant, i.e. we can point it to somewhere else.
      • The data 1 is constant; we cannot change the value at that address via this pointer.

    • constant pointer to a non-constant: int * const ptr = 1

      • The pointer itself is constant, i.e. we cannot point it to anywhere else.
      • The data 1 is not constant, i.e. we are not prohibited to mutate the address ptr points to.

    • constant pointer to a constant: const int * const ptr = 1

      • Both the pointer and address being pointed to are constant, we may not point the pointer to other places or change value at this address via the pointer.

  • It helps to read variable definitions by string from the variable and working outwards:

    • const int *ptr: the pointer ptr is of int type which is restricted to be const
    • int * const ptr: the pointer ptr is restricted to be const which points to an int
    • const int * const ptr: the pointer ptr is restricted to be const which points to an int which is restricted to be const
Manipulating String

  • strlen(s): the length of s not including the null terminator

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    5
    1
    size_t strlen(const char *s) {
    2
        size_t n = 0;
    3
        while (*s++) ++n; // tricky, does testing and incrementing at the same time
    4
        return n;
    5
    }

  • strcpy(t, s): copy content from s to t 

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    5
    1
    char *strcpy(char *target, const char *source) {
    2
        char *t = target;
    3
        while (*t++ = *source++); // yikes
    4
        return target;
    5
    }

    • Assignment has a value -- the assigned value.

      • The expression *t++ = *source++ has the copied character being its value.
      • If a null terminator is copied over, the condition would fail and while loop ends.
      • After the assignment, both t and source are incremented.

    • Note that the target string must have enough space to hold the string (otherwise have fun)

  • strcat(t, s): append t to s and produce a new string.

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    6
    1
    char *strcat(char *target, const char *source) {
    2
        char *t = target;
    3
        while (*t) ++t; // we first reach the end of the first string
    4
        while (*t++ = *source++); // now copy over the second string 
    5
        return target;
    6
    }
    • strcat does not allocate new memory, which means target (the first string) must have enough memory to hold the second string (otherwise have fun)

  • strcmp(s1, s2): compare strings.

    • We cannot use the built-in equality operator == since it would expression simple pointer equality rather than test whether two distinct strings contain the same sequence of characters. In other words, s1 == s2 would always return false unless they actually point to the same object (string/char array).
    • The function strcmp produces 0 if they are equal; negative if s1 is lexicographically less than s2 and positive otherwise.
Taking Input Using scanf

  • Consider

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    3
    1
    char name[20];
    2
    printf("What is your name?");
    3
    scanf("%s", name);
    • Note that name is already a pointer, thus we use name directly instead of &name.
    • Next, when reading a string with %s, scanf will stop reading at the first occurrence of whitespace.

  • In the example above, name is long enough to hold 19 characters, but if user types more, scanf will continue to read into memory until it encounters a whitespace. This is a major source of buffer overflows.

  • Lesson: never use scanf with %s as there would be no way to prevent a buffer overflow. Instead, use a length-restricted variant of %s: scanf("%19s", name);.

Construct the format string at run-time
 
xxxxxxxxxx
5
1
char format[6];
2
int size = ...
3
    char *name = malloc( ... );
4
sprintf(format, "%%%ds", size);
5
scanf(format, name);

  • The function sprintf is like printf except that it prints it output to a string, in this case, the string format, instead of standard output.

  • The format specifier %% specifies a literal % sign. Thus the string variable format contains literally %ds where d is the value of size. 

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    17
    1
    #include <stdio.h>
    2
    int main() {
    3
        int size = 5;
    4
        char *format;
    5
        sprintf(format1, "%ds", size);  
    6
            // %d is replaced by 5
    7
        sprintf(format1, "%%ds", size);
    8
            // %% is replaced by a literal % so the output is %ds
    9
        sprintf(format1, "%%%ds", size);
    10
            // %% is replaced by a literal % so the string becomes %%ds
    11
            // the middle %d is still looking for an integer so %d is replaced by 5
    12
            // thus the entire string becomes %5s 
    13
            // => this is how to format a string at run-time.
    14
        printf("%s", format1); // 5s
    15
        printf("%s", format2); // %ds
    16
        printf("%s", format3); // %5s
    17
    }
Length-restricted Version of Above Functions
  • strncpy(target, source, n): copies the source string into the target string until it encounters a null terminator or until n characters have been copied. Note that, if the copying stops because n characters were copied (i.e. if source is at least n characters long), then strncpy does not add a null terminator and we need to do it manually.
  • Similar case for strncat and strncmp.
Some Errors
 
xxxxxxxxxx
4
1
char msg[6] = "hello";  // Correct:  'h', 'e', 'l', 'l', 'o', '\0'
2
char msg2[15] = "hello";  // Also OK.  Extra space for expansion
3
char msg3[5] = "hello"; // 'h', 'e', 'l', 'l', 'o'; no '\0'
4
char msg4[4] = "hello"; // truncated; likely compiler warning

MMIX: A Realistic Instruction Set

A More Realistic Processor

Motivation

  • Two important properties of physical memory that we have not taken into account:

    • Each word in memory has a fixed size.
    • Accessing large memory can be really slow.
Terminology
  • Most significant bit: leftmost bit, bit 63
  • Least significant bit: rightmost bit, bit 0
  • Most significant byte: leftmost byte, bit 63:56
  • Least significant byte: rightmost byte: bit 7:0
  • Wyde: two consecutive bytes with addresses
  • Tetrabyte: four consecutive bytes with addresses
  • Octabyte: eight consecutive bytes with addresses
Address of a Word
  • The address of a word is the address of its most significant byte, and the addresses of bytes in a word increase from left to right (known as a big-endian architecture).
  • Therefore address of words are always divisible by 8.
Two's Complement
  • To convert a positive binary number to a negative binary number, invert all digits then add 1 to it.
Registers

  • Rather than having operations use three memory addresses (as in PRIMP), we shall move to smaller and faster memory, known as registers.

  • In MMIX, each register holds 64 bits.

  • Von Neumann Architecture

The MMIX Architecture

Design

  • 256 general-purpose registers: $0 ~ $255

    • Available for arbitrary use.

  • 32 special-purpose registers: rA ~ rZ, rBB, rTT, rWW, rXX, rYY, rZZ

    • Have particular roles that help control the operations of the machine.
Execution of Instruction
  • A program is not a sequence of instruction; each instruction is encoded into one word of memory.
  • Every possible instruction is represented by a 32-bit pattern. There is no longer distinction between instruction and data that we used to maintain with PRIMP.
  • In order to execute one instruction, both a physical hardware processor and a software simulator would have to denote a bit pattern to extract information.
Software Interrupts
  • As the computer runs, certain events occur that require some kind of a response, e.g. errors. When they occur, control within the processor is diverted (interrupted) from its normal path into an event-handling path.
  • At this point, the processor looks at what kind of event took place (interrupt request number, IRQ) and uses this information to look up the interrupt handling routine defined by the OS.
  • The processor then invokes the procedure and afterwards return to its normal operation.
  • The same mechanism can be used to handle software interrupts -- interrupts specifically requested by the programmer through a special machine instruction. In this way, we can ask for the processor to run a specific OS-supplied procedure -- for example, a procedure to print.
  • In the case of MMIX, we can invoke a software interrupt via the TRAP instruction.

Technical Details: Starter Code for M1

Preamble
 
xxxxxxxxxx
10
1
        LOC 512
2
        GREG @ // Make $254 a global register, in addition to $255. 
3
               // They are not affected by push/pop
4
​
5
argc    IS $0  // X+1, X=Number of command line arguments
6
​
7
argv    IS $1  // Pointer to a null terminated array of pointers
8
               // pointing to each command line argument
9
lower   IS $2
10
upper   IS $3
  • LOC 512 : directive to load the program at memory location 512 (doesn't change anything for our purposes).
  • GREG @ : set the next non-global register to be global. Since $255 is always global, the next non-global register is $254
  • argc IS $0 : give an alias to register $0; argc is the number of command line arguments plus one. The first argument is the program name; if we are given two additional argument (e.g. lower and upper), argc would equal to 3 ($0 stores 3).
  • argv IS $1 : $1 stores the address of the start (first element) of the array of arguments; we can think of argv as a pointer to the start of the array.
  • lower IS $2 \\ upper IS $3 : give aliases to register $2 and $3. IS is part of the assembler directives; given Label IS Expression,it declares Label as a shorthand for Expression. In this case, lower can be used as a synonym for $2.
Main Function
 
xxxxxxxxxx
16
1
//      PUSHJ X,Y automatically saves register $0 to $(X-1),
2
//      makes them inaccessible for the callee, and jump to label Y. 
3
//      Those registers are automatically restored during POP.
4
​
5
Main    ADD argv,argv,8
6
        LDO $255,argv,0
7
        PUSHJ 4,Atoi // We are using $0-$3, so X=4
8
        ADD lower,$255,0
9
        ADD argv,argv,8
10
        LDO $255,argv,0
11
        PUSHJ 4,Atoi
12
        ADD upper,$255,0
13
        ADD $254,lower,0
14
        ADD $255,upper,0
15
        PUSHJ 4,Solve
16
        TRAP 0,Halt,0

  • Main : (label Main) - can be used as target to jump or branch.

  • ADD argv,argv,8 : (add argv argv 8) - arithmetic expression

    • Each MMIX instruction is exactly four bytes long. The first byte contains the operation code and the next three bytes may contain

      • 24 bit immediate data (e.g. JMP label)
      • 8 bit register number followed by 16 bit immediate data (e.g. SET $1,value)
      • most commonly, three 8 bit operands (e.g. ADD $1,$1,$2)

    • As for its effect in the program, this can be seen as "incrementing" argv by 1 (since each register occupies 8 bytes). For example, suppose $1 stores 200 (i.e. ; argv = 200, the array of arguments starts at address 200). Recall that the first argument in the array is always the program name, thus, in order to load the first "actual argument" (input from the user, lower as a string), we need skip the first argument (skip the program name). We achieve this by pushing argv one register ahead, i.e. instead of dereferencing *argv we are doing *(argv+1).

  • LDO $255,argv,0 : (move-octa (255) argv) // move as in PRIMP but only an octabyte - loading data

    • O stands for octa (8-byte); T stands for tetra (4-byte); W stands for Wyde (2-byte); B stands for Byte (1-byte). This notation is used very commonly in MMIX (loading data, storing data, etc.)

    • Remark. MMIX does not have double indirection (no nested pointers).

    • LDO $X $Y /$Z

      • Notation: /$Z means the operand can be either an immediate value or a register.
      • The program would load the data at $Y + /$Z into register $X.

    • LDO $255,argv,0

      • Suppose $1 stores 200 (i.e. ; argv = 200), the array of arguments start at address 200.
      • argv + 0 = argv = 200. This is the part where we do $Y + /$Z.
      • Then 200 will be loaded into the global register $255; we can now access the start of array from this global register.

    • Recall from last step that argv has been incremented already and is pointing to the string lower. We now load data from argv into the global register $255 for further use.

  • PUSHJ 4,Atoi : This is a function call; PUSHJ stands for push and jump.

    • The first argument specifies the size of the current called stack frame, which is either an immediate value (as in this case) or an indirect value (say $X); registers $0 to $(X-1) are considered as the caller's local variables which become inaccessible during subroutine execution and will be fully restored after return.
    • In this case, we have occupied registers $0 through $3 (see last code block), so we push these four registers onto the stack (this was the first step to enter a function call, see the compiler/SIMP-F).
    • Atoi is a label and we jump to that line. This is like starting a subroutine.

  • ADD lower, $255,0 : (add lower (255) 0)

    • The function Atoi converts a string to a non-negative number (see code blocks below).
    • Assume we know that the return value is stored at the global register $255. This instruction basically copies the return value (a non-negative number, which is what we want instead of the string input from the user) to lower, the register $2. At this point, we have replaced the string stored inlower by its numerical value.

  • ADD argv,argv,8 : (add argv argv 8)

    • Same as before, we are done with processing lower so we increment argv and get ready to process upper.

  • LDO $255,argv,0

    • Same as before, we load the string upper into $255

  • PUSHJ 4,Atoi

    • Same as before, we push the first four register onto the stack and jump to subroutine.

  • ADD upper,$255,0

    • Same as before, we now replace the string upper (value of $3) by natural number upper.

  • ADD $254,lower,0

    • Now we copy the content in lower to the global register $254.

  • ADD $255,upper,0

    • Copy the content in upper to the global register $255.

  • PUSHJ 4,Solve

    • Push the first four registers onto the stack and jump to subroutine Solve (we are supposed to implement this part)

  • TRAP 0,Halt,0

    • Recall the software interrupts section from above. The TRAP instruction calls to the operating system; register $255 is used to pass parameters and return values.

    • The second argument is commonly used to specify the operation (in this case, halt the program). The third argument is used as a auxiliary parameter.

    • Some popular TRAP instruction include

      • TRAP 0,Fputs,StdOut

        • Note that$255 must store the address of the string your want to print. It does NOT store the actual content!

      • TRAP 0,Fgets,StdIn

        • Note that $255 must store the address of the address of your string buffer. It does NOT store the actual buffer!
Other Remarks

  • Comparing contents of two registers: CMP $X,$Y,/$Z

    • CMP will set register $X to -1, 0, or 1, depending on whether $Y is less than, equal to, or greater than $Z.

  • Branch if Zero: BZ $X, label

    • If $X is zero, the program would branch to label.
    • Other branch instructions include BP (positive), BN (negative), BEN (even), BOD (odd), BNN (non-negative), BNP (non-positive) and BNZ (non-zero) and are used in similar fashion.
    • Combining comparison and branch allows us to do things like while loop and if.

  • Returning from a subroutine: POP X

    • Recall that PUSHJ pushes the first X registers onto the stack and transfers control to the address specified by its second argument, a 16 bit relative address, similar to a JMP instruction.
    • Visually, registers from $0 to $(X-1) all become inaccessible during the subroutine and registers $(X+1), $(X+2) and so on contain the subroutine parameters. PUSHJ will re-number these registers so that the subroutine will find them always in registers $0, $1, etc. This matches our way of doing compilers.
    • To return from a subroutine, the first argument of POP specifies how many values we are returning and then jump back to the last function call. Thus POP 0 is similar to a single return; statement without any argument in C.

  • Setting registers (special register refers to those 32 registers with weird names)

    • GET $X,Z: moves the value of special register number Z to register $X.
    • PUT X,$Z: moves the value of register $Z to special register X.
    • LDA $X,label: computes an absolute address and puts in $X.
    • GETA $X,label: computes a relative address and puts in $X.

  • Popular special registers

    • rR: stores the remainder of last DIV operation.
    • rJ: stores next instruction to execute after returning from subroutine. Think of this as the place that stores PC, or the first argument of jsr.

  • Fast way of setting a register to 0: do an XOR operation on itself, i.e. XOR reg reg reg.

  • All computations in MMIX operate on registers and immediate values. If data resides in memory, we must load the bytes into registers first: LDB $X,$Y,$Z which has the effect $X <-M[$Y+$Z] (B can be replaced by W, T, O for obvious reasons).

  • As a side remark, the print function provided in Lushman's starter code of M1 does not print negative numbers (rip so much time wasted).

    ​

Technical Details: Lecture Note

Hello World
 
xxxxxxxxxx
4
1
         GETA $255,MyString  //puts MyString's address into $255
2
         TRAP 0,Fputs,StdOut
3
         TRAP 0,Halt,0       //halts the program
4
MyString BYTE "Hello world!",#a,0   //sequence of bytes

  • The first line is an example for GETA instruction; rather than copying the content (which is handle by operator GET, it copies the address of MyString to global register $255).

  • The second and third line are normal instructions for printing and halting.

  • The last line is where we define the string MyString:

    • Recall that a string occupies a consecutive block of memory. In this case it occupies 14 words of memory. The first 12 hold the string "Hello world!", the 13th is a new line character (#a in hex is decimal 10, translating into ASCII is the newline character "\n"), and the last is a null-terminator. Visually, it would look like ["Hello world!"]++[\n]++[\0].
    • Byte is how we allocate data; we can also allocate memory of other sizes using Wyde, Tetra and Octa; they follow the pattern label BYTE expression, where label is like the variable name; BYTE tells you the size, and expression is just your data.
Printing a Two-digit Number
 
xxxxxxxxxx
10
1
end  GETA $255,Buf   // $255 <- Buf
2
     DIV $3,$1,10    // $3 <- first digit
3
     GET $4,rR       // $4 <- second digit, see remark about rR above
4
     INCL $3,'0'     // convert $3 to ASCII
5
     INCL $4,'0'     // convert $4 to ASCII
6
     STBU $3,$255,0  // M[$255] <- $3 "store byte unsigned"
7
     STBU $4,$255,1  // M[$255+1] <- $4
8
     TRAP 0,Fputs,StdOut
9
     TRAP 0,Halt,0
10
Buf  BYTE "  ",#a,0  buffer string to hold characters

  • Buf BYTE " ",#a,0 : this is the buffer string which holds our characters.

  • GETA $255,Buf: $255 now contains Buf's address.

  • STBU $3,$255,0: writes one byte to main memory. Note that this line interacts with our main memory instead of only registers.

  • STBU $4,$255,1 : the last line stores the first digit at (dereferencing $255 gives us the address of buffer string), now this line stores the second digit at , i.e. the next spot in the memory. Hence our buffer string finally holds the converted number and we are ready to print it out.

    ​

Towards a SIMP to MMIX Compiler

Additional Complications

  • All of the techniques used for the SIMP to A-PRIMP compiler are relevant here, but there are additional complications, such as:

    • Size of numbers - SIMP uses unbounded numbers but MMIX stores fixed-sized words

      • Solutions:

        • Racket: bignums, i.e. array of big digits as in C7.
        • C: fixnums, i.e. we restrict the size of numbers.

      • Remarks

        • Most imperative language implementations ignore overflow.
        • Addition of two 32-bit numbers produces at most a 33-bit result, but the multiplication of two 32-bit numbers may produce a 64-bit result. MMIX uses a special-purpose register to hold the upper 32 bits of result of an unsigned integer multiplication.

    • Alignment: MMIX expected addresses to be divisible by 4, so you may need to "pad" your string, if their lengths are not divisible by 4.

    • Access Speed: it is faster to use registers than memory locations. We will worry about this next year (rip).

Module 5~6: Racket Interpreter

Functional Language

Storing Primitive Values

Static Typing: How C Treats Stuff

  • Recall when compiling SIMP to PRIMP, our compiler/assembler uses a symbol table to translate variables names to memory locations. 

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    14
    1
    <SIMP>
    2
    (vars ([i 5] [j 6]) ...)
    3
    ​
    4
    <Memory>
    5
    addr    content
    6
    ...     ...
    7
    80      5
    8
    84      6
    9
    ...     ...
    10
    ​
    11
    <Hash Table>
    12
    id      addr
    13
    i       80
    14
    j       84
    • The value associated with variable may be in a fixed location or in a stack frame. This is also done by a C compiler/assembler due to static typing (the size of the data named by a variable is known at compile time).

  • However for a Racket interpreter, since a variable may refer to data of different sizes at different points during the computation (dynamic typing), we need to replace the compile-time symbol table by a run-time environment, which maps variables to locations and we need the values stored in the heap to be tagged with their type.

Dynamic Typing: How Racket Treats Stuff
  • Every Racket value is represented as a pointer to a tagged value on the heap.
Arithmetic Example

  • Example: (define x 3)

    • Suppose the interpreter places 3 at location 8 and returns 8.

    • The association of x with location 8 is added to the environment.

    • Note that, if the value can fit into one word, we may unbox x, or put its value directly into the environment.

    • Visual representation:

       
      xxxxxxxxxx
      10
      1
      (define x 3)
      2
      ​
      3
      <memory>
      4
      addr    content
      5
      4       <short int>
      6
      8       3
      7
      ​
      8
      <environment>
      9
      id      addr
      10
      x       8

  • Example: (define y x)

    • x is recursively evaluated, resulting in a reference to memory location 8, which binds to y in the environment

    • Visual representation:

       
      xxxxxxxxxx
      12
      1
      (define x 3)
      2
      (define y x)
      3
      ​
      4
      <memory>
      5
      addr    content
      6
      4       <short int>
      7
      8       3
      8
      ​
      9
      <environment>
      10
      id      addr
      11
      x       8
      12
      y       8
      • Note that memory is unchanged; we didn't create anything new on the memory; all we did was creating another id-addr pair which maps the variable y to a location (that was already existed) on the memory.

  • Example: (define z (+ x y))

    • Both x and y are recursively evaluated; the sum is 6 and is stored into heap. Note that we need a type tag for it.

    • Visual representation:

       
      xxxxxxxxxx
      16
      1
      (define x 3)
      2

Cons Example

  • A cons cell uses three memory words: <a> <b> <c>

    • <a> is a type tag <cons> indicating that the next two memory addresses are part of this cons cell.
    • <b> is a pointer pointing to the "value" of the current element.
    • <c> is a pointer pointing to the next cons cell.

  • Example: (define x 3) (define lst1 empty)

    • x -> 8 -> 3 as before.

    • lst1 is mapped to empty, which by convention is represented by a zero.

Mutation: set!
  • set!rebinds a name to a new value (changes the name-value pair).
  • To evaluate (set! x exp), the interpreter recursively evaluates exp, then changes thee environment entry for x so that it is associated with the address of the resulting value.
  • I'm too lazy to put another visual representation here. Just know that this time the environment would change. For example, in the diagram above, if we (set! x y), since y is mapped to address 44, x would be mapped to 44 (and thus dereferencing x gives us 5 as desired).

 

Sharing and Aliasing Demystified

Racket List Example

  • New cons cells (and structs), as well as values and their tags, are allocated by the interpreter from the heap. Every use of the cons primitive results in such an allocation.

  • Before vs. After

    • We see that the two tree have different (two copies of) roots, different left subtree, but share the same right subtree (12). In other words, we have two copies of a node if we have traveled to that node; the other subtree on this level will be shared.
Advantage/Disadvantage of Memory Sharing
  • If we use this in C, how will we deallocate these lists? In the list example above, if we deallocate ans completely, then ex2 will become a dangling pointer; if we don't deallocate the last two nodes, then when do we do that? If we never free them, we create a memory leak.
  • Because C does not have a built-in garbage collector, creating an entirely new copy of lists (and other structs) is preferred.
  • Destructive ADT operation: (set! t1 (add-bst! t1 5 "test"))
Structural and Pointer Equality

  • Consider

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    3
    1
    (define list1 (list 3 4 5))
    2
    (define list2 (list 3 4 5))
    3
    (define list3 list1)

  • eq? tests for pointer equality (thus constant time).

    • (eq? list1 list2) => False
    • (eq? list1 list3) => True

  • equal? tests for structural equality (not always constant time).

    • These three lists are equal to each other under equal?.
Tail Recursion

  • Tail-call optimization is where you are able to avoid allocating a new stack frame for a function because the calling function will simply return the value that it gets from the called function. With tail-call optimization, the function takes constant stack space.

    • Environment frame: the name of each formal parameter/local argument is pair up with the corresponding memory address where the argument value can be found. It is removed from the symbol table when the function application or local expression is reduced to a value. It is not exactly a stack because of functions that produce lambda values.

  • Example:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    15
    1
    ;; Not tail recursive: O(n) space
    2
    (define (get-input)
    3
      (local ((define c (read-char)))
    4
             (cond
    5
              [(eof-object? c) empty]
    6
              [else (cons c (get-input))])))
    7
    (get-input)
    8
    ​
    9
    ;; tail recursive: O(1) space
    10
    (define (get-input acc)
    11
      (local ((define c (read-char)))
    12
             (cond
    13
              [(eof-object? c) (reverse acc)]
    14
              [else (get-input (cons c acc))])))
    15
    (get-input empty)

Imperative Language

Motivation

  • Issues solved:

    • Reading an S-expression.
    • Representing it as a data structure.

  • Issues left:

    • Avoiding deep recursion by using loops where possible.
    • Optimizing tail-recursion if it exists in the interpreted program.
    • Replacing garbage collection in the Racket interpreter.
    • Garbage collection in the interpreted program if the interpreted language supports lists.

  • We want to convert our Racket interpreter to tail-recursive and then translate into a loop.

allSteps :: Ast -> Val -- do all steps and produce a value
29
allSteps (Number v) = Numb v -- if given a number, produce a number object
30
allSteps (Fun fp fb) = Fn fp fb -- if given a function, produce a function object
31
allSteps x = allSteps (oneStep x) -- otherwise, apply oneStep recursively
  • Despite allSteps is tail-recursive (this is obvious since we only do one thing at a time), we can only descent to find the redex; there is no way we could ascend (i.e. main a sense of "current element"). One imperative solution is to use a double-linked list with a current element pointer (as in C).
  • To do this in a purely-functional way, we can use a data structure containing two lists, representing "ahead" and "seen" respectively. To be able to generalize later, we shall represent the "seen" list by a new data type called contexts.
Ahead and Seen

  • Consider

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    2
    1
    data Cxt a = F a [a] | MT
    2
    type CList a = ([a], Cxt a)

  • Suppose our example list is [1,2,3,4]. We represent this list as ([1,2,3,4],MT). Moving forward results in ([2,3,4], F 1 MT]); moving forward again results in ([3,4], F 2 ( F 1 MT)]). We see that the "seen" list is kept in "reverse" order thus moving backward takes only constant time:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    7
    1
    forward :: Clist a -> Clist a
    2
    forward ([], _) = error "can't go forward in an empty list"
    3
    forward ((x:xs), c) = (xs, F x c)
    4
    ​
    5
    back :: Clist a -> Clist a
    6
    back (_, MT) = error "can't go backward from start of list"
    7
    back (xs, F x c) = (x:xs, c)

  • Exercise: modification, insertion, deletion

  • To do this with a tree, we need to keep track of the direction we descend, i.e.e we need another parameter:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx

Continuation

  • We create a data constructor for each possible way of moving forward in the AST that is useful for the interpreter, and store whatever information is necessary to back up.

  • Since we are working with tail-recursion, we don't need to wrap the continuation together with the AST, as in the examples above; we can simply add it as a new parameter.

  • Our interpreter will now consume two arguments, an AST, and a continuation. If the root of the AST is a Bin or App, it descends.

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    4
    1
    data Cont = MT | AppL Ast Cont | AppR Val Cont | BinL Op Ast Cont | BinR Op Val Cont
    2
    ​
    3
    interp (Bin op x y) c = interp x (BinL op y c) 
    4
    interp (App f x) c = interp f (AppL x c)
    • We see the continuation grows.

  • In the remaining cases, the AST represents a value, so we can "apply" the continuation to the value. For clarity, we split this out into a separate function.

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    10
    1
    interp x c = applyCont c x
    2
    ​
    3
    applyCont :: Cont -> Val -> Val
    4
    applyCont (BinL op y k) x = interp y (BinR op x k)
    5
    applyCont (BinR Plus (Numb x) k) (Numb y) = applyCont k (Numb (x+y))
    6
    applyCont (BinR Times (Numb x) k) (Numb y) = applyCont k (Numb (x*y))
    7
    ​
    8
    applyCont (AppL a k) f = interp a (AppR f k)
    9
    applyCont (AppR (Fun fp fb) k) x = interp (subst fp x fb) k
    10
    applyCont MT x = x
    • The reason that we can evaluate/interpret BinR and AppR is that, if we have already reached that point, we know the left argument must be simplified already.
    • In fact, the continuation plays the role of the stack, and we see that the stack does not grow when the function is tail recursive.

  • Now we have made the interpreter fully tail-recursive, we can add mutation now. Before that however, we have two mutually-recursive functions, interp and applyCont, both tail-recursive. We need to find a way to use them.

Trampolining

  • We write a trampoline function, which calls the first tail-recursive function to start the computation. Instead of that function calling another function in tail position, it returns a "bounce" to the trampoline. The "bounce" is a data structure that contains the information needed for the trampoline to call the next tail-recursive function (i.e. name and arguments). This results in bounded stack depth.

  • Racket Implementation

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    5
    1
    (struct bounce (function args))
    2
    (define (trampoline x)
    3
      (if (bounce? x)
    4
          (trampoline (apply (bounce-function x) (bounce-args x)))
    5
          x)))

  • To use this in C, we can use global variables and make the mutually-recursive functions have no formal parameters. Each function takes its arguments from the global variables when called, puts the arguments for the tail call into global variables, and return (to the trampoline function) a function pointer to the next function to be called. This allows us to avoid the trouble with function pointer involving type and numbers of arguments.

MISC

Garbage Collection

First technique: reference counting

  • In every chunk of heap-allocated memory, we maintain a "reference count" of the number of pointers that point to it. This count starts at one when the chunk is allocated and is incremented each time we copy a pointer. It is decremented when the code frees a chunk containing a pointer, or returns from a function having a local pointer variable pointing to the chunk, or mutates a pointer variable (pointing to somewhere else) that was pointing to the chunk. When the reference count is decremented to zero, the chunk is freed.

    • Advantage: it can be done on the fly.
    • Disadvantage: circular pointers.
Second technique: mark and sweep

  • The set of active heap chunks can be found at any point by a "graph reachability" search from the current environment and continuation and they are marked in the course of the search. A subsequence "sweep" through the memory reclaims chunks that are not marked (not used).

    • Advantage: buried in the allocation wrapper function.
    • Disadvantage: takes time and uses a lot of stack memory (as itself is recursive)
Fragmentation
  • Both system have a weakness: they do not address fragmentation of memory, the situation where lots of small allocated blocks are scattered through memory preventing consolidation of free chunks into larger ones. This happens a lot if we want to allocate different-sized structures.
  • One common solution is the buddy system: we start with blocks of some small size , pair them up to blocks of size , and so on. We maintain a free list of each block size. When allocation request arrives, we try to satisfy it by the next largest block size, if that size is not available, but the next larger one is, we split it in two, put one on the free list and the other one to the request. When the program frees memory, we try to repeated merge free blocks to make the largest free block we can. Eventually we get to a free block that cannot be merged and we put that on the appropriate free list. It certain reduces but still does not fully eliminate fragmentation.
Third technique: Copying Garbage Collection
  • Read this: http://www.cs.cornell.edu/courses/cs312/2003fa/lectures/sec24.htm

  • A union is similar to a struct, except that instead of having all of the listed fields, the union has only one of them. The compiler sets aside enough space to hold the largest type. Thus, the construction of AST specifies that an Ast is either an App or a Fun, but nothing else. Note that, if we store an Ast as App, we must treat it as an App; doing Fun stuff on Ast is illegal.

        struct Fun *f;
11
    };
12
};
13
​
14
struct App {
15
    struct Ast *f, *x;
16
};
17
​
18
struct Fun {
19
    char *x;
20
    struct Ast *body;
21
};
  • Anonymous union: we may access the field a and f directly as fields of Ast without having to explicitly first access the union as a separate field and then access fields within the union.
  • Enumeration: creates a set of constants to denote a discrete set of alternatives. We would then use the enumeration field t to remember what type the union is currently holding.

 

Multidimensional Arrays in C

 
xxxxxxxxxx
9
1
int x [5][10]; // array of 5 elements, each of which is an array of 10 ints.
2
​
3
// Sum
4
int i, j, a = 0;
5
for (i = 0; i < 5; ++i) {
6
    for (j = 0; j < 10; ++j) {
7
        a += x[i][j]; // access consecutive items
8
    }
9
}

  • Remark: looping over the row first is faster than looping over the columns first. Reason is obvious)

  • Remark: when passing a multidimensional array as an argument, only the first dimension may be left unspecified.

  • Remark: as a result of the last remark, it is common to use arrays of pointers instead of two dimension arrays:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    5
    1
    int **y = malloc(5 * sizeof(int*)); // each y points to a pointer which points to an integer array.
    2
    ​
    3
    for (int i = 0; i < 5; ++i) {
    4
        y[i] = malloc(10 * sizeof(int));
    5
    }

  • Remark: a call to malloc(n) produces a contiguous block of bytes. We can approximate 2-dimensional behaviour by allocating an array of size , and then providing our own indexing function:

     
    xxxxxxxxxx
    4
    1
    int *p = malloc(5 * 10 * sizeof(int));
    2
    int get(int *a, int rowSize, int i, int j) {
    3
        return a[i * rowSize + j];
    4
    }
